column1: Uttaradit (Thai: อุตรดิตถ์
column2: pronounced [ʔùt.tā.rā.dìt]) is one of Thailand's seventy-six provinces (changwat)
column3: lies in upper northern Thailand. Neighboring provinces are (from south clockwise) Phitsanulok
column5: Phrae and Nan. To the east it borders Xaignabouli of Laos. Uttaradit is 488 km north of Bangkok
column6: and 238 km southeast of Chiang Mai.

column1: Uttaradit means the "port of the north" or "northern landing"
column2: as it was formerly a trade center on the Nan River.In the Sukhothai era several city states (Mueang) subject to the king were in the area of the modern province. Mueang Fang was in modern-day Mueang Uttaradit district
column4: and Mueang Ta Chuchok in Tron district.

column2: Mueang Phichai was one of the 16 main Mueang of the Thai kingdom. In the reign of King Naresuan
column4: joined by the ruler of Sawankhalok. Their revolt was suppressed and the inhabitants of both cities were forced to move south to Phitsanulok.

column1: Following the fall of the city of Ayutthaya to the Burmese in 1767
column2: Phichai was the site of several battles against the invaders. The ruler of Phichai succeeded in driving back the Burmese and was awarded the title Phraya Phichai Dap Hak - the "Lord of Pichai with a Broken Sword"
column3: as he had broken one of his swords in fierce hand-to-hand combat with the enemy.

column1: In the reign of King Rama III Mueang Phichai controlled several Mueang of northern Siam like Nan or Phrae
column2: and even Luang Prabang and Vientiane. At the point where the Nan river became shallow a port was established. As this town grew in importance as an important trade point
column3: in 1887 it was made a Mueang subordinate of Phichai. 1899 the center of Phichai was moved to this new location
column4: which was renamed to Uttaradit in 1915.

column1: The province is in the Nan River valley. About 45 kilometers north of the city of Uttaradit is the Queen Sirikit Dam
column2: which created a 250 km² artificial lake. The Phi Pan Nam Range reaches the northwest of the province.

column1: Most of the province was once covered with teak forests

column4: but it was damaged in a storm.

column6: the giant teak tree is part of the 35 square kilometer park of mixed deciduous forest.

column1: The province is divided into nine districts (amphoe). These are further divided into 67 subdistricts (tambon) and 562 villages (muban).

As of 26 November 2019 there are: one Uttaradit Provincial Administration Organisation (ongkan borihan suan changwat) and 26 municipal (thesaban) areas in the province. Uttaradit has town (thesaban mueang) status. Further 25 subdistrict municipalities (thesaban tambon). The non-municipal areas are administered by 53 Subdistrict Administrative Organisations - SAO (ongkan borihan suan tambon).
Uttaradit's main hospital is Uttaradit Hospital
column2: operated by the Ministry of Public Health.

column1: Uttaradit is served by the Northern Line of the State Railway of Thailand. There are two stations in Uttaradit town: Uttaradit railway station
column2: the main station and Sila At railway station
column3: where it is a major centre for Northern Line operations. It does not have an airport. The nearest airport is in Phitsanulok Province.
